HEADLINE: NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse Consider Deal Options

BYLINE: MARK SCOTT


HIGHLIGHT: The $9 billion merger could be in jeopardy if European anti-trust authorities force more concessions from the exchanges, including the potential sale of the company's lucrative derivatives businesses. 

 BODY:
LONDON -- The $9 billion merger between Deutsche Borse and NYSE Euronext could be in jeopardy if European anti-trust authorities force more concessions from the exchanges, including the potential sale of the company's lucrative derivatives businesses.
Regulators have raised concerns that the pending merger would reduce competition in the fast-growing exchange derivatives sector. The financial firms already have announced the sale of some of their overlapping businesses, but said they may not continue with the deal if regulators demand further concessions.
"We want to pursue the transaction, but not at all costs," Deutsche Borse chief financial office Gregor Pottmeyer said in a statement late on Wednesday. "Antitrust conditions should not be allowed to endanger the industry and economic logic of this transformational merger."
The European Commission has until Jan. 23 to make a decision about the merger, but officials have been in close discussions with the firms in recent weeks, according to people familiar with the talks.
In response to the European Commission's initial demands, the companies in November agreed to concessions that they hoped would seal the merger. NYSE Euronext said it would sell its pan-European single equity derivatives units, except the options businesses in its home markets. Deutsche Borse also said it would divest similar operations.
The companies added they would give rivals access to Eurex Clearing, a clearinghouse for derivatives products, to offset regulatory concerns that the pending merger would lead to uncompetitive practices.
The companies, though, remain adamant that the European Commission should approve the merger. 
"European authorities have a stark choice to make," said a person briefed on the matter. "It can allow the transaction to proceed that will free up $4 billion of capital when things are coming apart at the seams in Europe, or it can let the deal fall through."
Regulators have centered their attention on the competition issues within the exchange-traded derivatives sector. Yet William Rhone, a senior analyst at financial consulting firm TABB Group in New York, said the real competitive issues lie in the so-called over-the-counter market, dominated by many of the world's largest investment banks, that still represents the majority of derivatives trades in Europe. 
Under new global regulatory proposals, these opaque deals are being forced to use clearing houses -- financial intermediaries that guarantee trades if one side defaults -- and to trade on exchanges.
"The NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse is an attractive proposition that will allow them to compete with the oligopoly of the OTC dealers," Mr. Rhone said. "It's that market, not the exchanges, where the debate about competition should be."

(Ford)

The two companies abandoned negotiations in 2007 for reasons undisclosed by the sources. G.M. reportedly is looking for manufacturing capacity outside of Thailand, where severe flooding hampered many automakers' ability to produce vehicles there in October and November. (Bloomberg)
 Sauber has joined Red Bull and Ferrari in announcing its withdrawal from the Formula One Teams Association, according to a team spokeswoman unidentified in a report by Autosport. Red Bull and Ferrari left the association after citing frustration with the process of instituting and enforcing spending caps, though the spokeswoman for Sauber declined to discuss the reasons for the team's withdrawal. The Sauber driver Kamui Kobayashi finished in 12th place over all in the 2011 season. (Autosport)

HEADLINE: Catskills Deal for the New York City Watershed

BYLINE: MIREYA NAVARRO


HIGHLIGHT: A $5.6 million sale of a 1,200-acre parcel of pristine forest just east of the Belleayre Ski Center in the Catskills is said to restrict development and storm water runoff into the New York City watershed. 

 BODY:
An important state acquisition in the Catskill Park in New York is finally being completed four years after the purchase was brokered under Gov. Eliot Spitzer's administration.
The $5.6 million sale of the land, a 1,200-acre parcel of pristine forest just east of the Belleayre Ski Center, would restrict development and storm water runoff into the New York City watershed. The deal results from an agreement reached by the state, New York City, several environmental groups and the Crossroads Ventures real estate group in 2007. 
The agreement allows for future construction of a downsized private development project known as the Belleayre Resort at Catskill Park as well as an expansion of the state's Belleayre Mountain Ski Center.

The property will be added to a state forest preserve protected under the state constitution, officials with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said.
The department's commissioner, Joe Martens, the acquisition "preserves a major undeveloped geographic feature of the scenic Route 28 corridor in the heart of the Catskill Park." 
"The completion of this acquisition protects the Catskill Park while allowing economic growth in the area," he said.

SECTION: BUSINESS; economy

LENGTH: 824 words

HEADLINE: A Question for Newt Gingrich

BYLINE: SIMON JOHNSON


HIGHLIGHT: Newt Gingrich has not yet explained in any detail how he would rein in the biggest banks or what his ties to Wall Street are, an economist writes. 

 BODY:
Newt Gingrich has surged in recent polls and now has a chance to establish himself as the front-runner in the Republican presidential primaries. But as Mr. Gingrich ascends, he will need to answer a difficult question: What is his policy for Wall Street's too-big-to-fail banks?
This a pertinent issue for all American voters in 2012 - both for the primaries and for the general election. It speaks directly to who wins and who loses in American society and why). 
It is also a question that Mr. Gingrich is likely to be asked during the Republican debate on Monday, perhaps in the context of Europe's financial problems (the planned topics for the debate between Mr. Gingrich and Jon Huntsman are national security and foreign policy). 
Mr. Gingrich's career path creates a number of potential vulnerabilities around this issue.

No doubt Mr. Gingrich will seek to deflect the issue - as he did on Oct. 11, during a previous debate, when in response to a Wall Street-related question he said, "If you want to put people in jail, you ought to start with Barney Frank and Chris Dodd." 
This was a crowd-pleasing one-liner - Representative Frank and former Senator Dodd have their names attached to the financial reform legislation of 2011, and bashing that bill is standard Republican rhetoric.
But Mr. Gingrich will find it difficult to avoid the substance of this issue for much longer for a simple reason: Mr. Huntsman has figured out that breaking up megabanks is both sensible economics and good Republican primary politics. 
Mr. Gingrich claims to be the true conservative, but the awkward - for him - truth is that on all issues related to the financial sector, Mr. Huntsman has the conservative high ground. He understands that "too big to fail" is not a market, it's a government subsidy program, and that these subsidies are large, hidden, unfair and incredibly dangerous. 
As I explained last week, Mr. Huntsman is drawing on deep thinking around these issues by some of the most serious intellectuals on the right of the American political spectrum. He is also tapping into the deep and articulate resentment in the American nonfinancial sector; people who run the businesses that generate most of the jobs in the United States fully understand that the current structure of Wall Street does not serve us well.
So it will be hard for Mr. Gingrich to respond adequately on substance. As Mr. Huntsman told Bloomberg News, speaking of other presidential candidates more broadly: 
They want to be able to point out the deficiencies in front of some crowds, but they want to take money from the banking sector. They're not going to get contributions from the banking sector if they're specific about how they want to remedy the situation.
Mr. Gingrich was reported to be in New York this week, seeking to raise a lot of money quickly. It seems reasonable to presume that much of the available quick money is close to the heart of Wall Street.
Mr. Gingrich will also have to address the issue of whose money he took while speaker of the House in the mid- to late 1990s. This was a period in which big banks were pushing hard for the repeal of Glass-Steagall - the last remaining restrictions on what they could do and, effectively, on their scale. 
Mr. Gingrich may argue that it was the Clinton administration that argued forcefully for full financial-sector deregulation, and there is some evidence that is so. But there was also a bipartisan consensus around the issue and, as far as I can ascertain, Mr. Gingrich was a central part of that.
There was an intense debate on details during Mr. Gingrich's tenure, and a great many campaign contributions entered the fray. I have not yet seen a detailed analysis of what Mr. Gingrich received and what he oversaw - and from whom. Presumably such information will be forthcoming as his candidacy advances. 
Mr. Gingrich could, of course, now turn his back on megabanks - and brand them a dangerous form of European lemon socialism (socialized losses; private gains). He did say something vaguely along these lines in 2010.
But this is not the time for vagueness or generalities. Mr. Huntsman has a specific, detailed financial overhaul program that offers the most plausible way forward for forcing the big banks to become substantially smaller and also safer. I've discussed this approach with leading experts, both on the right and on the left, and my assessment is that these are the most ambitious and most sensible proposals we have seen from any politician.
Mr. Gingrich has no such plan - at least not on his Web site or elsewhere in the public domain.
So, Mr. Gingrich, do you agree that too-big-to-fail banks should be broken up, as Mr. Huntsman has proposed? What are your detailed, specific proposals for how to do this? Will you endorse Mr. Huntsman's plan?

HEADLINE: The Early Word: Looking Both Ways

To the gatekeepers of the Obama administration, it is no matter that the mounds of State Department documents released by the anti-secrecy organization Wikileaks remain available online. Scott Shane explains that the administration still considers some of the information to be secret, a position that those who advocate government transparency say is absurd.
A federal judge in Illinois sentenced former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich to a 14-year prison term for 18 felony corruption convictions, counts that include trying to sell or trade President Obama's former Senate seat, Monica Davey reports.
Two Democratic operatives who served President Bill Clinton have moved their rivalry from Washington to Hollywood, where both have characters modeled after them in dark political dramas about winning elections at all costs, Adam Nagourney writes.
Happening in Washington:
President Obama will meet with the Democratic leadership of the House before taping a round of regional television interviews. In the evening, he will speak at the White House's Hanukkah reception.
At 9:30 a.m., Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. will testify before a House Judiciary subcommittee with oversight of the Justice Department.
At the same time, the House Agriculture Committee will examine the bankruptcy of MF Global. The panel has subpoenaed the company's former chief executive, Jon S. Corzine, who used to be governor of New Jersey.
Economic data expected today include jobless claims at 8:30 a.m. and weekly mortgage rates at 10, simultaneous with the Labor Department's annual snapshot of work experience for 2010.

HEADLINE: Live Blog: House Panel Hearing on MF Global

BYLINE: ERIC OWLES


HIGHLIGHT: Jon S. Corzine, the former chief of MF Global, is appearing before the House Agriculture Committee on Thursday to answer questions about the collapse of his brokerage firm. The panel began at 9:30 A.M. 

 BODY:
 Jon S. Corzine, the former chief of MF Global, is appearing before the House Agriculture Committee on Thursday to answer questions about the collapse of his brokerage firm and the disappearance of up to $1.2 billion in customer money. The panel began at 9:30 A.M.
4:47 P.M. | Corzine Is Dismissed
This concludes our live blog coverage. The final group includes a food company industry representative, financiers and regulators. 

        
John Fletcher of the National Grain and Feed Association, a food company representative.
        
Terrence Duffy of the CME Group, the major exchange where MF Global did business.
        
William J. Brodsky of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, one of MF Global's regulators.
        
Dan Roth of the National Futures Association, a self-regulating group for the futures industry.
        
Stephen Luparello of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.
        
Gerry Corcoran of the Commodity Markets Council, a trade association.
Their prepared testimony is available on the House committee's web site.
4:43 P.M. | Where the Buck Stops
"The buck stops here," Mr. Corzine told Representative Renee L. Ellmers, Republican of North Carolina. "On that score," he added.
Ms. Ellmers questioned Mr. Corzine about his relationship with Mr. Gensler since their time together at Goldman Sachs. Mr. Corzine said they were not in contact on a frequent basis.
4:39 P.M. | Confusion Over Regulators
Representative Reid J. Ribble, Republican of Wisconsin, asked about the number of regulatory agencies. "Can we regulate greed, incompetence and fraud out of existence?"
Mr. Corzine allowed that the brokerage firm's collapse may have been due instead to poor judgment. "Mistakes will continue to happen in the course of human events."
4:34 P.M. | Questions on Corzine's Ties With Democratic Regulators
Representative Tim Huelskamp, Republican of Kansas, questioned Mr. Corzine about his meetings with the regulators.
Mr. Corzine said he did not have separate conversations with Mr. Gensler. 
"You're very close to the administration," Mr. Huelskamp said. As a generous campaign bundler did you meet with anyone in the administration?
Mr. Corzine said he never discussed MF Global with anyone in the Obama Administration.
4:29 P.M. | Addressing the Farmers
Asked how he would address farmers who have lost money in MF Global, Mr. Corzine said he could not offer specific advice. 
"This process of seeking to find these funds is one that absolutely needs every resource possible," Mr. Corzine said.
4:22 P.M. | Grading the Rating Agencies
Representative Scott R. Tipton, Republican of Colorado, asked Mr. Corzine about how the rating agencies grades of the brokerage. Mr. Corzine allowed that in hindsight they were not appropriately rated.
"Everyone felt an obligation to get the books reconciled," Mr. Corzine said.
Mr. Corzine on the European sovereign debt investments: "With the analysis and the perspectives on how those particular sovereigns were looked at we thought they were prudent investments."
4:16 P.M. | Corzine Declines to Speculate
Representative Austin Scott, Republican of Georgia, thanked Mr. Corzine for answering as many questions as he had.
Mr. Corzine said he didn't want to speculate on when the commingling of funds first occurred.
4:11 P.M. | An Increase in Risk
Representative Jean Schmidt, Republican of Ohio, cited a Bloomberg News report suggesting that Mr. Corzine had increased the company's risk. "At some point you had to know there wasn't enough money." Ms. Schmidt said. 
She asked if he was hiding the risk of MF Global's investments in Europe. Mr. Corzine said the information was public.
"Why were you so confident about these bets?" Ms. Schmidt asked.
They were less risky because financing was in place, Mr. Corzine said.
"Sitting here today," Mr. Corzine said, "it would have been better to have taken different judgments."
4:05 P.M. | Appetite for Risk
Representative Terri A. Sewell, Democrat of Alabama and a former securities lawyer, asked Mr. Corzine about the company's appetite for risk before and after his arrival. The former MF Global chief said it stayed "pretty much" at the same level.
4:00 P.M. | The Role of J.C. Flowers
Representative Jeff Fortenberry, Republican of Nebraska, repeated his question for regulators: who owned MF Global? I'd like to understand the whole interconnections here, he said. "Who hired you?"
Mr. Corzine said the board member from J.C. Flowers suggested his name when the previous chief of MF Global stepped down.
What we have here is inordinate risk-taking, Mr. Fortenberry concluded.
3:52 P.M. | Investing Overseas
Representative Joe Courtney, Democrat of Connecticut, asked about the impact of the new C.F.T.C. rules and repurchase agreements.
Mr. Corzine repeated the portion of the rule about allowing the investment of funds overseas from foreign currency-denominated deposits.
3:47 P.M. | 'We're Not the Prosecutors'
Representative K. Michael Conaway, Republican of Texas, opened with a question about Mr. Corzine's involvement in segregated funds. 
The former MF Global chief said a problem would have been brought to his attention. Mr. Corzine said he did not personally place orders.
Mr. Conaway asked when Mr. Corzine first took steps to protect the company from a liquidity risk. Mr. Corzine said the plan was to rely on undrawn credit lines held in reserve.
There was never any intent in my language or actions, Mr. Corzine said.
I understand why you're using the word intent, Mr. Conaway said. "We're not the prosecutors."
3:39 P.M. | Find That Money
Representative David Scott of Georgia opened with much harsher statements than other Democrats. Mr. Corzine immediately focused his answers on MF Global's board of directors.
Mr. Corzine said there was never any direct intent to co-mingle customer funds with proprietary funds. He also denied that he stood in the way of increased C.F.T.C. regulations.
"Mr. Corzine, we got to find that money," Mr. Scott said.
3:32 P.M. | The Best Intentions
Mr. Corzine told Representative Randy Neugebauer, Republican of Texas, that he never "intended" to authorize anyone to tap into segregated funds.
"So the answer is you don't know whether you did or not," Mr. Neugebauer said.
The Texas congressman questioned Mr. Corzine about his relationship with the Fed, a not-so-subtle reference to the former Democratic lawmaker's ties to the Obama administration. 
3:26 P.M. | Listen to Your Mother
Mr. Corzine said he upheld the motto of Representative Dennis Cardoza's mother to always behave properly when no one was watching.
Mr. Corzine said that he was with his chief financial officer when he first learned about the missing customer funds and that his first instinct was to recheck the numbers.
3:20 P.M. | And Now We Turn to New Jersey
Representative Steve King, Republican of Iowa, pushed harder on Mr. Corzine than the Democratic congressman from Iowa. Mr. King questioned why MF Global would invest in specific European countries.
Mr. Corzine said investments were not made with the belief that Greece would be bailed out.
Mr. King then questioned the former governor of New Jersey about budget shortfalls in the Garden State. Mr. Corzine said his former state treasurer has already responded to those numbers.
3:15 P.M. | Boswell Asks for a Message
Representative Leonard Boswell, Democrat of Iowa, asked Mr. Corzine what lawmakers should say to their constituents who have lost money in MF Global. 
Mr. Corzine said he hoped that the missing funds would be found. There is no question that futures markets and securities markets are essential for the United States economy.
3:12 P.M. | Replacing Missing Funds
Representative Timothy V. Johnson, Republican of Illinois, called for Mr. Corzine to commit his personal fortunes to replacing the missing customer funds. 
Mr. Johnson also asked why Mr. Gensler wasn't recused from oversight of MF Global earlier. He chastised Mr. Corzine for negligence, co-mingling or abnegation of his responsibility.
3:07 P.M. | Looking for More Precision
Representative Tim Holden, Democrat of Pennsylvania, questioned Mr. Corzine about the documents he claims he requires to be more precise in his answers and quickly yielded back his time.
3:05 P.M. | An Agreement on Confusion
Representative Bob Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia, began with questions about Mr. Corzine's role in overseeing customer funds. The congressman went over the timeline of when the former MF Global chief became aware of the missing funds.
Mr. Corzine blamed it on a miscalculation in "the last few hours and last few days."
Mr. Corzine and Mr. Goodlate agreed on one thing. They are confused about the reports in the public sector.
2:59 P.M. | Hitting the Buttons
Mr. Corzine said he was not aware of customer funds being transferred to the broker commodity. There was no intention on my part to violate the segregation rules, he said.
Mr. Corzine declined to name individuals who should have directly managed the transfer of funds. He said he didn't know who would have ultimately have hit the buttons.
2:50 P.M. | Recess Is Over
Mr. Peterson is questioning Mr. Corzine now about the missing customer funds.
2:11 P.M. | Corzine's Responses
Mr. Corzine has responded to all the questions posed by Mr. Lucas and Mr. Peterson, but his answer is often that he lacks the proper documents. The former MF Global chief has not pleaded the Fifth, but so far he has not answered questions as directly as lawmakers may have liked. We are still waiting for the panel to resume.
1:57 P.M. | Beware Roving Lawmakers
@kaylatausche Kayla Tausche
Don't worry - am okay! Congressman just walked in front of shot, caught my mic cord and brought me down to the ground! #OccupyCongress
Thu Dec 8 18:47:07 via Kayla Tausche
1:37 P.M. | So Many Titles, So Little Time
Mr. Peterson began his inquiry asking Mr. Corzine about his title. "Governor, senator, I don't know exactly what to call you," he said.
A lot of people have bad names, Mr. Corzine responded.
Mr. Lucas warned that the panel would break soon for a series of votes.
1:27 P.M. | Questions for Corzine Begin
"Is there a shortfall in the customer funds that MF Global was legally required to keep segregated?" Mr. Lucas asked.
"I know only what I read," Mr. Corzine said.
Mr. Lucas's next line of questioning was more direct. He asked why Michael Roseman, the chief risk officer of the company, was warning about the MF Global's exposure to European debt.
Mr. Lucas then focused on reports that Mr. Corzine threatened to leave the firm if the board did not trust his judgments. 
1:15 P.M. | Corzine Points Toward MF Global's Board
@m_delamerced Michael de la Merced
Corzine putting some responsibility for the RTM trades on #mfglobal board. All "independent, sophisticated" directors.
Thu Dec 8 18:14:24 via Michael de la Merced
"I simply do not know where the money is," Mr. Corzine said.
1:09 P.M. | Corzine Begins His Prepared Testimony
Mr. Lucas began by asking Mr. Corzine to stand for the administering of the oath and asking if he had the right to counsel. Mr. Corzine then began reading from his prepared testimony.
"Like all of you, I am devastated by the enormous impact on many people's lives resulting from the events surrounding the MF Global bankruptcy. Of course my distress and sadness pale in comparison to the losses and hardships that customers, farmers and ranchers and others, employees and investors have suffered. Their plight weighs on my mind every day."
"As the chief executive officer of MF Global at the time of its bankruptcy, I truly apologize to all those affected."
1:05 P.M. | The First Panel Is Dismissed
Mr. Corzine, a former Democratic senator from New Jersey, is up next.
His prepared testimony is available on the House committee's web site, but it offers little insight into the missing money. DealBook has noted the .
It appears he will try to place some of the blame for collapse of the brokerage firm on his predecessors.
1:00 P.M. | A Call for More Reporting on Segregated Funds
Representative Christopher Gibson, Republican of New York, asked about the daily segregated reports. Ms. Sommers said that with the C.F.T.C. already examining MF Global they were able to monitor events over the weekend before the brokerage declared bankruptcy. 
12:40 P.M. | More on the Missing Funds
Mr. Kobak on the difficulties in locating the missing customer funds:
All of the property is held in foreign locations and foreign administrators. Experience tells me it will be a longer process than it is domestically, Mr. Kobak said.
The trustee is taking all the steps he can take, "but that might mean going to litigation," Mr. Kobak explained. Insolvency rules in some parts of the rules don't always work the way they do in the United States.
12:34 P.M. | Gensler, Gensler, Gensler
Representative Tim Huelskamp, Republican of Kansas, joined a list of lawmakers who have peppered Ms. Sommers about Mr. Gensler's absence. Congressmen continue to tie Mr. Gensler to Mr. Corzine, via Goldman Sachs.
12:15 P.M. | Lessons Still Being Learned
Representative Henry Cuellar, Democrat of Texas, asked for lessons learned that would change regulation policies. Ms. Sommers said it may be too soon to answer that question, but that better protection is needed for customer funds. "We don't yet have all the facts," Ms. Sommers said.
12:13 P.M. | More Money Possible for MF Global's Customers
Mr. Kobak said he is asking the bankruptcy court tomorrow for permission to distribute more money to MF Global's customers.
11:55 A.M. | Can We Get the C.T.F.C. a Digital Subscription?
Questioned about DealBook's coverage of MF Global, Ms. Sommers said that "I'm not familiar with the article."
11:39 A.M. | Gensler Comes Under Attack Again
Representative David Scott, Democrat of Georgia, also criticized Mr. Gensler for recusing himself and asked about Mr. Corzine's ability to influence the C.T.F.C. MS. Sommers deflected the question with an explanation of the tougher constraints that were passed on Monday.
"First of all I find it very unacceptable that Commission Chairman Gensler is not here," Mr. Scott said. "That he has recused himself. That is has gone out of the country at the very time that we're faced with the largest - the eight largest bankruptcy in the history of the United States on a firm that comes under his oversight."
11:27 A.M. | We're Back in Session
... with more questions for the first panel.
11:15 A.M. | In Other Financial Regulatory News
President Obama is set to speak at 11:30 AM in the White House briefing room to address his attempts to push a vote this week on the confirmation of a director for the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
10:45 A.M. | We're in Recess
In her final statement, Ms. Sommers told Representative Dennis Cardoza, Democrat of California, that financial companies were not engaged in transactions that were too complex for the C.F.T.C. to understand, but that "it's just tracing the amount of different accounts and the transactions from one place to the other."
Ms. Sommers said she was unsure when regulators would find the money.
"We can't over emphasis the complexity of MF Global's books and regulators," she said, adding that "at the end of the day, we'll know."
- 
10:26 A.M. | Criticism of Goldman Sachs
Representative Timothy V. Johnson, Republican of Illinois, attacked "the Goldman Sachs fraternity" and questioned why Gary Gensler, chair of the C.T.F.C., had recused himself from the inquiry. Mr. Gensler and Mr. Corzine are former employees of Goldman Sachs.
"Is that because he's part of this whole same Goldman Sachs fraternity that includes ministers of foreign governments in which the money's invested, Mr. Corzine himself, Mr. Gensler himself, and this whole nebulous group of individuals?" Mr. Johnson asked. "Is that why he's decided to recuse himself, because he's part of that group, or why did he do that?"
"I do not know," Ms. Sommers said.
10:19 A.M. | Criticism of Regulators
Lawmakers want to know whether MF Global's watchdogs were asleep. Ms. Sommers replies that the C.F.T.C. the "is not the front line regulator." That job belongs to for-profit exchanges like the CME Group.
- 
10:13 A.M. | DealBook Gets a Shout-Out!
 Mr. Peterson mentions our story about investigators suspecting that MF Global transferred some customer money to JPMorgan in Britain. Mr. Peterson wants to know whether JPMorgan was responsible for verifying the legitimacy of the funds.
Mr. Peterson:
On November 29, the New York Times, there was an article by Ben Protess and Azem Ahmed about how some investigators suspect that there was a transfer of some $200 million from MF Global to J.P. Morgan Chase in Britain. And it may have been the first major misuse of customer money it was reported. It's also said that the authorities are looking into whether J.P. Morgan initially questioned the source of this cash and sought proof of MF Global that it was complying with regulations.
- 
10:06 A.M. | The Questions Begin
"It has become clear that there were warning signs at MF Global in the weeks, if not months leading up to the bankruptcy, increased exposure in foreign sovereign debt, increased leverage, insufficient capital. Was the C.F.T.C. aware of these warning signs?" Mr. Lucas asked Ms. Sommers. The question reveals the complexity of the regulatory structure over MF Global. We will see a number of other regulators whose agencies oversaw the failed brokerage in the third panel today.
There's no real way to overemphasize the complexity this, Ms. Sommers said.
9:45 A.M. | Panel One: The Witnesses
Mr. Corzine is scheduled to appear in the second panel today. 
First up is Jill E. Sommers, a Republican commissioner with the C.T.F.C. who is leading the inquiry in the absence of the agency's head. Also testifying is James Kobak, a lawyer for the trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global's brokerage unit.
@m_delamerced Michael de la Merced
RT @n23mc: We should ask, "Should SIPC cover futures accounts like they do equity accounts?" What do you think? // What's everyone think?
Thu Dec 8 14:42:54 via Michael de la Merced
9:41 A.M. | The Hearing Has Begun
"I'd like to make it clear that our intention is not to sensationalize the events that have unfolded," said Representative Frank Lucas, Republican of Oklahoma and the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee. Mr. Lucas the primary goal should be to return the missing customer money.
The opening statement from the ranking Democrat reveals that lawmakers are already looking beyond today's hearing. "Given what happened here, we should probably be talking about strengthening Dodd-Frank, not weakening it," said Representative Collin Peterson, the ranking Democrat.
Mr. Peterson took a swipe, "It appears to me that nobody has learned a thing from what's gone on here; that Wall Street is operating as if 2008 never happened."
- 
9:31 A.M. | Police Shielding Corzine
@kaylatausche Kayla Tausche
There was also a wall of 3 police officers shielding him from the press, though a few of us stuck our mics out anyway. #Corzine#MFGlobal
Thu Dec 8 14:30:32 via Kayla Tausche
9:29 A.M. | Tracking Other Investigations
Congress is not alone in seeking the missing customer funds. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is leading the search, but the trustee overseeing the liquidation of MF Global's brokerage unit is also hunting for the $1.2 billion. Last week, Gary Gensler, the head of the C.T.F.C. removed himself from the inquiry following questions about his ties to Mr. Corzine, his former boss at Goldman Sachs. "Now, the worry is that the commission will stumble in its rare turn on center stage without its star leading the way," Ben Protess and Azam Ahmed reported.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is separately examining a potential criminal case. Mr. Corzine has not been accused of any wrongdoing by law enforcement.
9:28 A.M. | Live Video Has Begun
It's not the most exciting video in the world, but you can watch people entering the room now on C-SPAN.
9:25 A.M. | Other Congressional Subpoenas
Today's hearing won't be the former senator's last trip to Capitol Hill. The Senate Agriculture Committee issued a subpoena for Mr. Corzine to testify at a Dec. 13 hearing. The oversight subcommittee of the House Financial Services Committee will will hold a hearing on Dec. 15.
9:24 A.M. | Corzine Is in the Building
@kaylatausche Kayla Tausche
Corzine just entered around a back hallway. Said nothing, holding coffee and folder of papers. #MFGlobal
Thu Dec 8 14:24:13 via Kayla Tausche
9:21 A.M. | Why the Agriculture Committee?
Some DealBook readers have asked why Mr. Corzine is appearing before the Agriculture Committee instead of the Financial Services Committee. As Ben Protess reported, "customers of the brokerage firm included farmers and agriculture companies, as well as hedge funds and other investors."
9:11 A.M. | 10 Questions for Corzine
Mr. Corzine has stated that he will try avoid using of his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. If he responds to today's inquiries then lawmakers may want to look over the list of questions compiled by DealBook columnists Steven M. Davidoff and Peter J. Henning.
For example, "why did you feel the need to personally trade for MF Global instead of having a trader or trading group do it? Who did you speak to structure and monitor this trade, particularly since you were preoccupied with running this entire business?"
9:05 A.M. | A Preview of Today's Tone
On Dec. 1, the Senate Agriculture Committee questioned MF Global's regulators about the firm's collapse. That panel may provide a preview of what we can expect today.
9:00 A.M. | Corzine's Prepared Testimony Is Made Available
The House Agriculture Committee has posted all of the prepared testimony on their web site.
DealBook reports that Mr. Corzine "is expected to defend his decision to invest heavily in European sovereign debt, saying in his first public appearance since the firm filed for bankruptcy that he was "stunned" by the huge shortfall in client funds."
"Considering the circumstances, many people in my situation would almost certainly invoke their constitutional right to remain silent - a fundamental right that exists for the purpose of protecting the innocent," Mr. Corzine said in prepared testimony. "Nonetheless, as a former United States Senator who recognizes the importance of congressional oversight, and recognizing my position as former chief executive officer in these terrible circumstances, I believe it is appropriate that I attempt to respond to your inquiries."
"I remain deeply concerned about the impact that the unreconciled and frozen funds have had on MF Global's customers and others," he said in the written testimony.

PUB-DATE: December 8, 2011

SECTION: BUSINESS; media

LENGTH: 735 words

HEADLINE: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 8

BYLINE: NOAM COHEN


HIGHLIGHT: Political operatives go Hollywood, Romney goes to Iowa (through Fox News), charities go soft-sell and Medvedev goes there on Twitter. 

 BODY:
Adam Nagourney writes about Jay Carson and Chris Lehane, two former Democratic operatives in Washington who serve as the models for political consultants in different Hollywood movies. The Carson-inspired character was at the heart of "The Ides of March," directed by George Clooney; Mr. Lehane is a writer and producer of "Knife Fight," slated for release early next year, which also focuses on a political consultant. Both worked for President Bill Clinton, Mr. Nagourney writes, and "not surprisingly, each movie has an older male candidate who has sexual relations with an intern." But more generally, he writes that the movies "go beyond the usual Hollywood glorification of political consultants, offering dark and at times unsettling accounts of what is done in the name of winning elections."

        
"If there were a Fox News primary, Mitt Romney would be losing it," Michael Shear , based on the most recent New York Times/CBS News poll of Republicans in Iowa. Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, gets the support of nearly half of the Fox News watchers, while just 12 percent of the regular Fox watchers said they would vote for Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, in the Iowa caucuses next month. The Fox News bloc is sizable: nearly 40 percent of those Iowa Republicans surveyed said they get most of their news from the channel. (On that note, Mr. Romney has agreed to appear on "Fox News Sunday with Chris Wallace" on Dec. 18 interview, his first Sunday morning interview in roughly 20 months.)

        
Politico sets the stage for what it calls the "alpha dog" debate. While G.O.P. encounters this primary season seemingly blurred one into the other (when Donald Trump wasn't the scheduled host, that is), Politico writes that Saturday's ABC News/Des Moines Register debate at Drake University will stand out as "the first to reflect the new campaign order now that the GOP race has narrowed to a two-man contest between Gingrich and Romney."
The official Twitter account of Russia's president, Dmitri Medvedev, reposted an obscene message directed at political opponents of the Kremlin. Retweeting such a crude message "appeared to run contrary to Mr. Medvedev's image as an educated, Twitter-savvy leader," Reuters wrote. He has more than 700,000 followers on Twitter. The Kremlin confirmed that an "improper retweet" had appeared on the account and said an unidentified official was to blame. "The guilty will be punished," it said in a statement, Reuters reported.
Charities are trying the soft-sell this holiday season, Elizabeth Olson reports, when as much as half of donations can occur. The American Red Cross, citing a survey that found that despite a struggling economy, consumers say they will keep up charitable giving, has introduced a claymation figure called Fred. "Instead of the guilt-laden approach, we are trying a new visual identity that is approachable and friendly," said Peggy Dyer, chief marketing officer for the American Red Cross. Similarly, she writes, Oxfam America has introducing a "cheeky animated video featuring the actress Scarlett Johansson."
The Styles section looks at how customer service has changed at L.L. Bean. In addition to the 3,600 employees who answer customers' phone calls, "a 10-member team was recently created to interact with customers on social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter," writes Susan Q. Stranahan from Lewiston, Me. She quotes Terry Sutton, a senior vice president for e-commerce at the company, who notes the special skills that are needed now that complaints can be broadcast via social-networking: "We are quite used to dealing one-to-one with our customers, but this takes it to a whole new level."
Howard Beck described his recent assignment in a Reporter's Notebook for Sports: 156 hours in some of New York's finest hotels, where "I did not sleep, or shower, or earn rewards points." He was covering the N.B.A. lockout, which ended Nov. 26 with a new labor agreement that is expected to be ratified on Thursday. Twitter and text-messaging connected him to the fans who cared about every twist and turn, he writes.
During one late-night session at the Waldorf-Astoria, I heard from a Twitter follower in Australia. He was just getting out of work. My friend David Aldridge of TNT said he received Twitter responses from six continents that night. Everywhere but Antarctica, where I'm guessing the Wi-Fi is a little sketchy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Blog

SUBJECT: TELEVISION PROGRAMMING (90%); TELEVISION NEWS SHOWS (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2012 (90%); FILM (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (90%); INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING (90%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (90%); INTERVIEWS (89%); NETWORK TELEVISION (88%); CHARITIES (87%); PRIMARY ELECTIONS (78%); MEN (78%); CAUCUSES (78%); POLITICS (78%); ELECTIONS (78%); FILM DIRECTORS (78%); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS (76%); VOTERS & VOTING (76%); POLLS & SURVEYS (74%); ANIMATION (73%); WRITERS (73%); TELEVISION INDUSTRY (72%); US PRESIDENTS (71%); RELIEF ORGANIZATIONS (60%); CHARITABLE GIVING (60%) Lehane, Chris; Medvedev, Dmitri A; Romney, Mitt; Wallace, Chris; News and News Media; Television; Fox News Channel; Politico, The; Twitter; advertising; Breakfast Meeting; Marketing; Movies; New Media

COMPANY: FOX ENTERTAINMENT GROUP INC (95%)

ORGANIZATION: Fox News Channel; Politico, The; Twitter

INDUSTRY: NAICS515120 TELEVISION BROADCASTING (95%); SIC4833 TELEVISION BROADCASTING STATIONS (95%)

PERSON: MITT ROMNEY (92%); DMITRY MEDVEDEV (79%); BILL CLINTON (73%); NEWT GINGRICH (58%); GEORGE CLOONEY (57%); DONALD TRUMP (50%) Lehane, Chris; Medvedev, Dmitri A; Romney, Mitt; Wallace, Chris

GEOGRAPHIC: IOWA, USA (94%); MASSACHUSETTS, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (94%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (85%)

The Kremlin confirmed that an "improper retweet" had appeared on the account and said an unidentified official was to blame. "The guilty will be punished," it said in a statement, Reuters reported.
Charities are trying the soft-sell this holiday season, Elizabeth Olson reports, when as much as half of donations can occur. The American Red Cross, citing a survey that found that despite a struggling economy, consumers say they will keep up charitable giving, has introduced a claymation figure called Fred. "Instead of the guilt-laden approach, we are trying a new visual identity that is approachable and friendly," said Peggy Dyer, chief marketing officer for the American Red Cross. Similarly, she writes, Oxfam America has introducing a "cheeky animated video featuring the actress Scarlett Johansson."
The Styles section looks at how customer service has changed at L.L. Bean. In addition to the 3,600 employees who answer customers' phone calls, "a 10-member team was recently created to interact with customers on social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter," writes Susan Q. Stranahan from Lewiston, Me. She quotes Terry Sutton, a senior vice president for e-commerce at the company, who notes the special skills that are needed now that complaints can be broadcast via social-networking: "We are quite used to dealing one-to-one with our customers, but this takes it to a whole new level."
Howard Beck described his recent assignment in a Reporter's Notebook for Sports: 156 hours in some of New York's finest hotels, where "I did not sleep, or shower, or earn rewards points." He was covering the N.B.A. lockout, which ended Nov. 26 with a new labor agreement that is expected to be ratified on Thursday. Twitter and text-messaging connected him to the fans who cared about every twist and turn, he writes.
During one late-night session at the Waldorf-Astoria, I heard from a Twitter follower in Australia. He was just getting out of work. My friend David Aldridge of TNT said he received Twitter responses from six continents that night. Everywhere but Antarctica, where I'm guessing the Wi-Fi is a little sketchy.

HEADLINE: Ballet Meets Colbert in Unusual Pas de Deux

BYLINE: JULIE BLOOM


HIGHLIGHT: David Hallberg, an American who has joined the Bolshoi Ballet, appeared on "The Colbert Report." 

 BODY:
"I was worried; what if I can't fire back?" David Hallberg said about his pre-show jitters before appearing Wednesday night on "The Colbert Report" on Comedy Central. The dancer, the first American to join the Bolshoi Ballet on a full-time basis, shouldn't have worried.
Despite Stephen Colbert's accusations that Mr. Hallberg was "Benedict Arnold in slightly tighter pants," the dancer gently reminded him that "the cold war's over." He went on to discuss his decision to leave the United States for Moscow to pursue his dreams in dance. "I love a challenge, I love risk," Mr. Hallberg said. Mr. Colbert responded: "There's nothing risky or challenging in the United States? Dance on fire. Do the 'Firebird' on fire."
Though Mr. Hallberg held his own in the interview portion, the same could not quite be said for Mr. Colbert during the performance part of the show. Mr. Hallberg danced an excerpt from American Ballet Theater's production of "The Nutcracker" with Hee Seo, a soloist with the company. Performing on flooring the show had installed for the dancers, Mr. Colbert, in his suit jacket and black tights and ballet slippers, soon joined in -- mimicking Mr. Hallberg's jumps and tours en l'air and briefly partnering Ms. Seo. At the end, snow fell from above and, in Bolshoi tradition, the audience threw 200 roses at the performers' feet.
(Before the interview and dancing, Mr. Hallberg warmed up with battement kicks backstage while Mr. Colbert interviewed the South Carolina Democratic Party chairman, Dick Harpootlian, about adding a referendum on corporate personhood to the Republican primary ballot.)
In the green room after the show Mr. Hallberg, 29, said he was happy to have been on. "I feel like Colbert's viewers are my contemporaries," he said. "This is a chance to show them the dedication dance requires and this is a valid art form."
He said he hadn't given Mr. Colbert too much advice except: "He was entering like a little weasel. When you enter from off camera, you need to present yourself."
He added he was happy to be stateside but was eager to return to Moscow. "I can't wait to get back," he said. "Moscow doesn't scare me anymore. I'm finding parts of the city I love. I'm so fulfilled."

HEADLINE: Huntsman Lashes Out At Romney and Gingrich

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: Jon Huntsman on Thursday accused his two leading rivals of being part of a Washington culture that is destroying trust with Americans. 

 BODY:
Jon M. Huntsman Jr. on Thursday accused his two leading rivals for the Republican presidential nomination of being part of a Washington culture that is destroying trust with the American people and blocking solutions to the nation's biggest problems.
In an interview with The Caucus, Mr. Huntsman, a former governor of Utah, said that electing Newt Gingrich or Mitt Romney to the presidency would add to the cynicism that people feel about politics and Washington.
"We don't need a lobbyist in chief. And we don't need a panderer in chief. We need a commander in chief," Mr. Huntsman said. He said the people "don't have lobbyists. They don't have attorneys. They don't have representatives on Capitol Hill."
Mr. Huntsman's comments came just hours before he delivers a speech that his aides are calling his "closing argument" in which he will urge a large-scale reform of the federal government as a way of restoring trust in Washington. Mr. Huntsman has struggled in national polls, but he has improved some in New Hampshire, where he is focusing all of his attention.
According to a copy of the speech obtained by The Caucus, Mr. Huntsman also lashes out at Mr. Romney and Mr. Gingrich as "no better" than President Obama when it comes to breaking faith with the American people. 
Mr. Romney, a former governor of Massachusetts, "will say anything to earn the voters' trust," Mr. Huntsman plans to say.
Mr. Gingrich, the former House speaker, "participated in the excesses of our broken and polarized political system," Mr. Huntsman will say in the speech. 
In the interview, Mr. Huntsman said that he would support whichever Republican becomes the nominee. But he made clear that he will not shrink from attacking his fellow Republicans in the final few weeks before voting begins.
"If you are in the hip pocket of Wall Street, you are not going to talk about 'too big to fail.' You're not going to be able to talk about 'no more bailouts,'" he said. "If you are in the hip pocket of K Street, you're not going to be inclined to take on Congress to call for term limits."
The harsh words are part of an evolving dynamic in the 2012 Republican contest in which candidates like Mr. Huntsman are eager to break out and appear more willing to criticize their rivals. Representative Ron Paul of Texas released an ad this week that accused Mr. Gingrich of "serial hypocrisy."
That contrasts with Mr. Romney and Mr. Gingrich, the two candidates who are leading in most polls, who are just beginning to take swipes at each other.
Mr. Huntsman's sharp tone in the speech is not reserved for Republicans. Mr. Huntsman accuses Mr. Obama of "jamming through" health care, "brazenly" ignoring deficit recommendations and employing "crony politics" during his three years in office. Mr. Huntsman was ambassador to China under Mr. Obama.
The speech also serves to lay out a government reform plan that Mr. Huntsman hopes will appeal to voters who are frustrated with the status quo in Washington.
The centerpiece of the seven-point plan is Mr. Huntsman's promise to send Congress a "Citizens Legislature Act" that would include a constitutional amendment imposing term limits on members of Congress.
Under his plan, representatives would be limited to six two-year terms and senators would be required to leave after two six-year terms. 
"We must save capitalism from crony capitalists, and return to our founders' vision of a limited government that protects free markets and provides a level playing field of opportunity," Mr. Huntsman says in the speech.
Other promises that Mr. Huntsman makes in the speech include: 
* To completely rewrite the tax code, eliminating "every last loophole, subsidy and carve-out."
* To cut spending in "every corner of government.
* To break up Wall Street banks so that taxpayer are never "held hostage" by a Sophie's Choice between "massive bailouts, or economic calamity."
* To adopt a comprehensive energy strategy, "systematically streamline" regulations and bring home troops from Afghanistan.
In the speech, Mr. Huntsman casts the proposals as the solutions to the broader issue of a breakdown of trust.
"Rather than a limited, efficient government that serves the public's interest, Washington has grown bloated and bureaucratic, captured and corrupted by swarms of lobbyists, influence peddlers and crony capitalists," Mr. Huntsman says.
He added that "the American people have been let down, time and again. They have lost confidence in how our nation is run. As a result, anxiety and worry have filled our nation's psyche."
And he concludes: "We are a country divided and suffering from self-doubt."
Whether that message can help resurrect Mr. Huntsman's presidential campaign is not clear. His campaign does not have much money to spread that message with commercials, though a super PAC financed in part by his father could help.
Mr. Huntsman will not be part of Saturday's debate in Iowa, having not met the threshold of 5 percent in a national poll set by the debate's organizers. Instead, he will hold a town-hall style meeting in New Hampshire that day and will participate in a one-on-one national security and foreign policy debate with Mr. Gingrich the following Monday.
Mr. Huntsman said that he was looking forward to that faceoff and predicted that Mr. Gingrich would "approach it as a professor; I will approach it as a practitioner." He said he had been disappointed by what he called "reality-show-like debates" of the past several months.
"It's been long on drama and short on substance at a time when the American people long for substance," he said.
For now, Mr. Huntsman is targeting only New Hampshire, where he has gained a small amount of ground recently. The campaign is hoping to kick-start his effort by making a better-than-expected showing on Jan. 10.
"People don't begin coalescing around a candidate until a week or 10 days out," Mr. Huntsman said. "We are moving up as opposed to down. Expect the unexpected. It's always the case in New Hampshire."

HEADLINE: Warner Music Says Losses Grew in the Quarter

BYLINE: BEN SISARIO


HIGHLIGHT: The company reported $707 million in revenue for the three months ending Sept. 30, down 6 percent from the same period last year. Its net loss for the quarter was up 124 percent from last year. 

 BODY:
The Warner Music Group reported increased losses for its fourth quarter and fiscal year on Thursday, with growth in digital music not enough to offset the company's interest costs and lagging overall music sales.
Warner, home to the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Green Day and Neil Young, had been publicly traded since 2005 but was taken private in July after it was bought by Access Industries for $3.3 billion. It continues to report financial returns because of its public debt obligations.
The company reported $707 million in revenue for the three months that ended Sept. 30, the last day in its fiscal year, down 6 percent from the same period last year; its net loss for the quarter was $103 million, an increase of 124 percent from last year.
For the full fiscal year, revenue was $2.87 billion, down 4 percent from the year before, and net loss grew 43 percent to $205 million.
Digital music sales continue to grow throughout the music industry, though they have never been enough to offset the decline in CD sales. At Warner, digital music accounted for 28.6 percent of revenue for the year, up from 25.4 percent last year. But revenue declined over all for both the company's recorded music and music publishing divisions.
"The digital revenue growth was more than offset by contracting demand for physical product," Warner said in its financial statement.
Total album sales in the United States have been up slightly for the year, but Warner blamed its "light release schedule" and costs related to the Access deal for its losses. The Access takeover cost Warner $46 million in professional expenses, and its interest expenses increased to $72 million from $47 million when it refinanced debts after the sale, the company said; its new debt obligations also have higher interest rates.
As of Sept. 30, Warner had $154 million in cash, down from $439 million last year, and $2.22 billion in long-term debt.
Warner, the third largest of the four major record companies, faces a changed competitive landscape with the recent sale of its smallest rival, EMI. If regulators in the United States and Europe approve the deal, EMI's record labels will be acquired by the Universal Music Group, already the largest company, and EMI's music publishing assets will go to Sony, leaving Warner in a distant third place.
Analysts and music executives have said that the EMI deal, reached last month, could take six months to a year to be approved. Universal has already committed to $680 million in divestitures, apparently in anticipation of antitrust challenges.
As expected, Warner also announced on Thursday that Edgar M. Bronfman Jr. would be stepping down as chairman on Jan. 31, but would remain on the board. Mr. Bronfman, the company's former chief executive, became chairman in August when Stephen F. Cooper, a corporate turnaround specialist, took over as chief executive. Mr. Bronfman's decision emerged after he sent a memo to Warner employees on Monday.
No new chairman was named.

HEADLINE: The President's Osawatomie Speech

BYLINE: ROSS DOUTHAT


HIGHLIGHT: A plausible diagnosis and a deeply flawed prescription. 

 BODY:
A little over a month ago, I wrote a column about the problems with contemporary liberalism's prescription for what ails the American middle class. My argument, in a nutshell, was that wage stagnation and social immobility are real issues, but that simply soaking the rich in order to invest more money in our existing public institutions (propping up Medicare and Social Security, preserving and expanding government employment, etc.) wouldn't necessarily do much to increase prosperity and mobility for the next generation of Americans, and might actually have perverse consequences instead.
If you were so inclined, you might consider the column my pre-buttal to the president's big speech in Osawatomie, Kansas last week, which combined a reasonably-accurate diagnosis of Middle America's economic problems with a prescription that consists of tax hikes for the rich, more government hiring for education and infrastructure projects (or at least infrastructure projects that don't offend rich environmentalists), and a mix of industrial policy and appeals to corporations' patriotism (which, as Mickey Kaus notes, just leads to more industrial policy down the road) to boost private sector employment. I'm sympathetic to some of the president's smaller-bore proposals: I'd like to see the payroll tax cut extended, for instance, because it takes us one step closer to abolishing the payroll tax entirely, and government support for basic scientific research (as opposed to specific companies like Solyndra) can sometimes deliver large returns on limited investments. But as David Frum notes, the West has already been trying a version of Obama's overall vision for the last decade or more, without achieving particularly encouraging results. Using rising tax revenues from the top 1 percent to increase public-sector hiring while putting off necessary structural adjustments till tomorrow (or the next day, or the day after that ...) was basically the economic policy of Britain's Blair-Brown government in the late 1990s and 2000s, and it ended in tears when the bust came and the tax revenues dried up. On this side of the Atlantic, too, this was roughly the blueprint that many blue states (and not a few red ones, for that matter) followed in the Bush era, compensating for middling job growth and middle class wage stagnation by expanding their payrolls faster than the private sector did. And even if this approach hadn't left states like California in the untenable position they occupy today, it would still be a profoundly depressing vision of the American economic future. As Frum writes of the president's speech:
The unblinking diagnosis of the ills of the U.S. economy in the first half of his Kansas speech builds to a conclusion that amounts to: Let's accept that our future prosperity will be very narrowly based, and instead use some of the proceeds of that narrow prosperity to create government jobs as consolation prizes for those who lose out in private markets.
I don't want to pretend that there is some perfect alternative to this approach to our economic challenges, and certainly the current Republican presidential field hasn't come close to articulating one. But I will say this: Even if - no, if - you have a deep belief in the government's ability to help underwrite the American Dream, you have an obligation to recognize the necessity of fundamentally restructuring the institutions of government (rather than just funding them at their projected levels in perpetuity), because as it stands they aren't getting the job done. The president's speech gestured at this reality, with lines about making government "more efficient and more effective, more consumer-friendly, more responsive to people's needs." But fundamentally, his pivot to the 2012 campaign has also been a pivot to a defense of business-as-usual, in which the rich pay, the government grows, and the millions of Americans who don't belong to public sector unions, work for favored industries, or draw on Social Security and Medicare are left waiting for the government's ever-more-expensive investments to trickle down to them.

HEADLINE: Former Treasury Official Rejoins Hellman & Friedman

BYLINE: PETER LATTMAN


HIGHLIGHT: Jeffrey Goldstein has rejoined the private equity firm as a partner after a two-year stint as a top lieutenant to the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner. 

 BODY:
A former senior Obama administration official is resuming his Wall Street career after a two-year stint in Washington. 
Jeffrey Goldstein, a top lieutenant to the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, has rejoined the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman as a partner. 
As the Treasury Department's undersecretary for domestic finance since 2009, Mr. Goldstein played a leading role in shaping the administration's financial policies in the wake of the global economic crisis, including implementation of the Dodd-Frank Act overhauling Wall Street regulation. He worked on everything from restructuring the housing market to overseeing the Treasury's bailout investments in the banks and automakers. 
Mr. Goldstein left his post in July. The White House has nominated Mary Miller, an assistant secretary at the Treasury Department, as Mr. Goldstein's replacement. 
"Jeffrey's commitment to public service at such a critical time for the U.S. economy was extraordinary and we are proud he was chosen to serve in such an important role," Philip Hammarskjold, chief executive of Hellman & Friedman, said in a statement. 
At Hellman & Friedman, Mr. Goldstein, 56, will return to focusing on investments in the financial services sector. He previously worked at the firm from 2004 to 2009, where he helped oversee its investments in LPL Holdings, a now-publicly traded broker-dealer based in Boston, and Grosvenor Capital Management, a privately held Chicago-based investment shop. 
Mr. Goldstein will also serve in a new client-relations role at the firm, and will be based in New York. 
Hellman & Friedman, which has its headquarters in San Francisco, recently struck one of the largest buyouts of the year when it teamed up with the Carlyle Group to acquire Pharmaceutical Product Development for $3.9 billion. 
Prior to joining Hellman & Friedman the first time around, Mr. Goldstein served as chief financial officer of the World Bank, where he worked under its president, James D. Wolfensohn. Before that, he worked with Mr. Wolfensohn in the private sector at the investment firm BT Wolfenshohn. 
An earlier version of this post gave an incorrect middle initial for the Treasury secretary. It is Timothy F. Geithner, not P.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Corzine Defends His Actions at MF Global

BYLINE: BEN PROTESS


HIGHLIGHT: At a House hearing on his firm's collapse, a humbled Jon S. Corzine insisted that he "never intended to break any rules" while running MF Global. 

 BODY:
9:05 p.m. | Updated 
WASHINGTON - Jon S. Corzine, who came to Washington in 2001 as a Democratic senator from New Jersey, made a humbling return on Thursday, defending his tenure as MF Global's top executive and sounding a note of contrition about the brokerage firm's startling collapse.
Mr. Corzine told the House Agriculture Committee that he was "stunned" when he learned late on Oct. 30 that about $1 billion of customer money could not be located, a discovery that thwarted a sale of the firm and led to its filing for bankruptcy. Regulators and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are now hunting for the money and examining potential wrongdoing at the firm.
 Thursday's testimony was his first public comments since the bankruptcy and came after the committee voted last week to subpoena him.
The former senator insisted that he always tried to "do the right thing."
"I never intended to break any rules," said Mr. Corzine, dressed in a dark suit but without his trademark sweater vest. "I know I had no intention to ever authorize the transfer of segregated moneys. I know what my intentions were." Mr. Corzine has not been accused of any wrongdoing.
He did not rule out possible wrongdoing at MF Global. In theory, an employee may have misused customer cash after misinterpreting the chief executive's words, he said.
Still, over three hours of testimony, Mr. Corzine danced carefully around questions touching on the scandal of the missing funds, using phrases like "never intended" and "not to my knowledge."
And he offered little insight into the whereabouts of the missing money. He surmised that one potential cause of the shortfall was the "extraordinary number of transactions during MF Global's last few days," calling it a "chaotic" period that was "extremely difficult" to "reconstruct."
Yet it was not known until Thursday whether Mr. Corzine would directly respond to the lawmakers' questions at all.
"Considering the circumstances, many people in my situation would almost certainly invoke their constitutional right to remain silent - a fundamental right that exists for the purpose of protecting the innocent," he said. "Nonetheless, as a former United States senator who recognizes the importance of Congressional oversight, and recognizing my position as former chief executive officer in these terrible circumstances, I believe it is appropriate that I attempt to respond to your inquiries."
Mr. Corzine, who ran Goldman Sachs before entering politics, eagerly defended his decision to invest heavily in European sovereign debt, saying that it was part of a crucial push to return the firm to profitability. The firm had a $6.3 billion bet on the debt of five European nations.
"At the time that MF Global entered into the transactions," he said, "I believed that its investments in short-term European debt securities were prudent."
The MF Global board, he said, approved the risk limits for the trades, which were set on a country-by-country basis. At times, he said, the firm exceeded those limits and "it took appropriate steps" to reduce the risk.
When MF Global filed for bankruptcy, Mr. Corzine said the firm was "within the risk limits set by the board of directors." He said that he resigned from the firm on Nov. 4 at the request of a senior member of the board.
Mr. Corzine, who was defeated for re-election as governor of New Jersey in 2009, also defended his dealings with regulators. Months before the firm failed, he began a personal lobbying blitz, urging regulators at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to weaken a rule that would rein in the use of customer funds. He took his pitch directly to the agency's chairman, Gary Gensler, who worked for Mr. Corzine at Goldman Sachs in the 1990s.
Their relationship has come under a microscope on Capitol Hill. Mr. Gensler recused himself from the investigation of MF Global after Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, raised questions about Mr. Gensler's past acquaintance with Mr. Corzine.
Now, some Republicans are criticizing Mr. Gensler for stepping back at such a crucial moment for the agency. Representative Timothy V. Johnson, Republican from Illinois, said on Thursday that it was "entirely unacceptable" for Mr. Gensler to not testify at the hearing. He also criticized what he has called a "Goldman Sachs fraternity."
Jill E. Sommers, a Republican member of the futures commission, has taken over the lead role on the case and testified on Thursday. Lawmakers asked her whether the agency should have sounded the alarm about MF Global before its final days.
Ms. Sommers replied that the agency was "not the frontline regulator." That job belongs to for-profit exchanges like the CME Group.
Lawmakers were not satisfied.
"It appears to me that no one has learned a thing; that Wall Street is still operating as if 2008 never happened," said Collin C. Peterson of Minnesota, the committee's ranking Democrat.
Mr. Corzine will remain a regular presence on Capitol Hill for weeks. Two other Congressional panels, the Senate Agriculture Committee and the oversight arm of the House Financial Services Committee, have also demanded that he testify next week.
The House panel on Thursday also heard testimony from the firm's regulators, including Ms. Sommers and the CME Group.
But throughout the stop-and-start proceedings, the attention was centered on Mr. Corzine. And with the world watching, he began his testimony with a mea culpa.
"I sincerely apologize, both personally and on behalf of the company, to our customers, our employees and our investors, who are bearing the brunt of the impact of the firm's bankruptcy," Mr. Corzine said.
"My sadness, of course, pales in comparison to the losses and hardships that customers, employees and investors have suffered as a result of MF Global's bankruptcy."
In its final days, MF Global tapped its customers' accounts to meet its own financial obligations, people briefed on the matter have said. The act violated a fundamental Wall Street regulation that firms never commingle customer money with company funds.
Mr. Corzine told the House committee that he learned of the missing money about 11 p.m. on Oct. 30. "I remain deeply concerned about the impact that the unreconciled and frozen funds have had on MF Global's customers and others," he said.
The former senator at times seemed comfortable sitting on the other side of the hearing room. When faced with questions about MF Global's complex trading, he took a professorial tone, explaining the intricacies of his business and even cracking an occasional smile.
And while lawmakers peppered Mr. Corzine with questions about his European sovereign debt bet and the missing money, they kept a cordial tone with their former colleague. One congressman even congratulated the former Goldman executive on achieving considerable wealth.

HEADLINE: Goodbye to 'Gays, Guns & God'

BYLINE: TIMOTHY EGAN


HIGHLIGHT: National polls suggest that Republican candidates have lost a few of their favorite wedge issues. 

 BODY:
How do you praise the sanctity of traditional heterosexual marriage when the best-known nuptials of the year, between a Kardashian and a basketball player, lasted all of 72 days? Or, for that matter, when a possible Republican nominee for president, Newt Gingrich, cares so much about marriage that he's tried it three times?
You don't. The above mockeries of marriage are just the latest reasons one of the most potent wedge issues of American politics - the banner of gays, guns and God - will have little impact next year. 
This trio is usually trotted out in big swaths of the West, in rural or swing districts and in Southern states at the cusp of the Bible Belt. The proverbial three G's was the explanation in Thomas Frank's entertaining book "What's the Matter With Kansas" for why poor, powerless whites would vote for a party that promises nothing but tax cuts for the rich.
It's misleading to think people will vote against their economic interests simply because a candidate doesn't mouth the same pieties as them as they do. But the cultural cudgel works to a point. I've certainly seen the three G's launched late in a campaign, to great effect. Jim Inhofe won a Senate seat in Oklahoma in 1994 using the three G's as an overt slogan. 
At the same time, I've watched smart politicians, like Montana's two-term Democratic governor, Brian Schweitzer, blunt the attack by showing off their guns and waving away the God and gay questions as none-of-your-business intrusions. 
But this year I think we've reached a tipping point on these heartless perennials. When George W. Bush won re-election in 2004, political sophisticates were stunned by a national exit poll in which 22 percent of voters picked "moral issues" from a list of things that mattered most - more than any other concern. This was heralded as the high-water triumph for evangelicals. 
Later analysis showed that the phrase "moral issues" was being used rather broadly by voters, from concern about character to worry over poverty. It was a catch-all. Still, the ranking of moral issues as the top reason to pick a president came as a surprise. 
Now look at this week's New York Times/CBS News Poll of likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa, about as conservative a cohort of voters as anywhere in the country. Iowa, for Republicans, is where gays, guns and God will grow in political fields long after corn is no longer planted for ethanol subsidies. 
Topping the list of voter concerns was the economy and jobs - picked by 40 percent of respondents, followed by the budget deficit at 23 percent. Social issues came in a distant third, with 9 percent. And the candidate who polled highest as the one who "most represents the values you try to live by," Michele Bachmann, has nothing to show for that rating in the overall race, where she is in fifth place. 
But the decline of the three G's hasn't stopped a few of the dead-enders in the Republican field from raising the flag. Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, last seen trying to find a verb to follow "oops," is out this week with a very specific culture-war ad in Iowa, vowing to end "Obama's war on religion," whatever that is. 
"I'm not ashamed to admit that I'm a Christian," says Perry, in a folksy drawl. "But you don't need to be in a pew every Sunday to know that there's something wrong in this country when gays can serve openly in the military, but our kids can't openly celebrate Christmas or pray in school." The surprise here is that he actually completed several sentences, though it may have required a number of takes. 
Perry and Rick Santorum, another badly wounded culture warrior, blasted Secretary of State Hillary Clinton this week for saying that the United States would assist human rights groups fighting for tolerance in countries where people have been imprisoned, and even killed, for their sexual orientation. 
"This administration's war on traditional values must stop," said Perry, siding, apparently, with mullahs living in caves. 
This is Perry's last gasp; in desperation, he shows how this particular balloon has run out of hot air. Poll after poll has found that Americans now overwhelmingly favor letting gays serve openly in the military - a sentiment backed even by a sizable majority of Republicans.
The gay marriage issue is moving in the same direction. Earlier this year, Gallup reported that, for the first time in its tracking of the issue, a majority of Americans believe same-sex marriage should be legal. In 1996, only 27 percent felt that way. 
Which brings us to guns. President Obama has done nothing to curb gun use. If anything, he's expanded gun rights. There are probably a dozen Democrats in Congress from the West who know more about guns than Mitt Romney or Professor Newt Gingrich. That dog, as they say, will not hunt - not this year. 
The irony is that two of the G's could actually hurt Republicans in 2012. Conservative orthodoxy is badly out of step with emerging majority support for full citizenship rights of gays. And with religion, some Republicans have already made an issue of Romney's Mormonism, and Gingrich's switch to Roman Catholicism. In Gingrich's case, questions have been raised about how a multiple-married man could win the favor of high-ranking Catholic clerics who usually look askance at people who ditch their wives.
Do we dare expect these two fine men to be the ones, at long last, to bring an end to the gays, guns and God wedge issue, even if it's by accident?

HEADLINE: Lousy Filibusters: Richard Cordray Edition

BYLINE: ANDREW ROSENTHAL


HIGHLIGHT: Republicans have blocked confirmation of Richard Cordray, President Obama&#8217;s pick to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Agency. 

 BODY:
It seems like only yesterday that Republicans blocked President Obama's nominee for the D.C. Circuit appeals court, Caitlin Halligan, for no good reason. Actually, it was two days ago, and the Republicans have already moved onto yet more obstruction. Today, they blocked the confirmation of Richard Cordray: President Obama's pick to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. 
In case readers haven't been following this particular drama, here's the background. The Dodd-Frank reform law, passed in response to the financial crisis, included language establishing a consumer protection agency that would shield Americans from deceptive lending through mortgages, credit cards and the like. (Those practices, you may recall, played a big factor in almost destroying the housing market, not to mention the economy.)

The Dodd-Frank law is not nearly strong enough. It stops well short of fixing the problems that caused the meltdown, including deeply inadequate regulatory oversight. But the CFPB concept seemed promising.
Republicans, of course, consider this agency a grave threat to the financial system. By which they mean it's a threat to their donors. An editorial we published in July explained that "banks-big campaign contributors-don't want robust consumer protection because complex and obscure products are lucrative." If there's a more charitable - but still reality-based - explanation for Republican opposition to the agency, I'd love to hear it.
Initially, the president wanted Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who'd pioneered the idea for the new agency, to actually lead it. But Republicans weren't going to let that happen. Blocking Ms. Warren was the next best thing to scrapping the whole agency, which cannot exercise its full regulatory powers without a director.
So the ever-obliging Mr. Obama passed over Ms. Warren, and in July tapped Mr. Cordray, the former attorney general of Ohio and current chief of enforcement at the agency. This was another pointless attempt by the administration to encourage Republican compromise. That attempt failed, of course. Senator Richard Shelby of Alabama responded charmingly to the news of Mr. Cordray's nomination. He said it was "dead on arrival."
Mr. Cordray has all the right credentials, but that doesn't matter. Today, 53 senators voted for Mr. Cordray, and 45 Republicans voted against ending debate on his nomination. In the Senate, you need 60 people to vote for a vote. And with that, another exciting episode of the CFPB drama has come to a close.
