HEADLINE: Holiday Theater, in Three Flavors

BYLINE: By ERIK PIEPENBURG

 BODY:
Instead of making Ebenezer Scrooge watch those instructive scenes from his past, present and future, perhaps the ghosts would have completed their Grinch-eradication mission faster if they'd taken him to a show. They might have come up with a list like this one, which divides some of this year's notable holiday productions into three loosely defined, Dickens-inspired categories: Past (for nostalgia lovers), Present (for current-events followers) and Future (for tech geeks or more adventurous-minded theatergoers). Tiny Tim may have wished God's blessings on everyone, but be aware that not all these shows are good for families with children.
PAST
THE Irish Repertory Theater reinvents Dylan Thomas's classic story in a concert version of ''A Child's Christmas in Wales.'' The show mixes traditional and contemporary Christmas music with Thomas's story of what happens to a boy on Christmas Day in Wales. Adapted and directed by the Irish Rep's artistic director, Charlotte Moore, the production includes Howard McGillin (seated above), Broadway's longest-running Phantom in ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' 
Theater 2020 is presenting ''A Radio Christmas Carol, '' a radio-play version of Dickens's story that features Foley artists onstage creating sounds out of everyday materials. The show is being performed in Brooklyn Heights at the 19th-century St. Charles Borromeo Church.
The material may be current, but the storytelling is old-fashioned in ''The Flying Latke,'' a children's Hanukkah show at the Flea Theater. The play tells the story of a boy named Danny Silverstein and a mysterious flying potato pancake that causes a U.F.O. panic, starting on the first night of Hanukkah. The work is adapted by Arthur Yorinks from his children's book.
The ghost of Dickens gets a star turn in a solo version of ''A Christmas Carol'' at the Canal Park Playhouse. Written by Greg Oliver Bodine and directed by David F. Chapman, ''A Christmas Carol, as told by Charles Dickens (himself)'' uses physical comedy to tell the story of Scrooge from the perspective of his creator. Brunch at the theater's Waffle Iron Cafe is available on Saturdays.
Two one-night-only shows merge the past and the present. On Dec. 17 an old art form gets an updating in the ''Gotham Burlesque Holiday Spectacular,'' featuring the performers Dirty Martini, Jo Weldon and Tigger! and hosted by the downtown entertainer known as World Famous *BOB*. On Dec. 12 Ann Harada, who originated the role of Christmas Eve in the musical ''Avenue Q,'' revisits the character in ''Christmas Eve With Christmas Eve,'' a benefit concert for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.
PRESENT
MOTHER GOOSE meets Occupy Wall Street in ''Little Lord's Babes in Toyland,'' a purposefully shoddy musical revamping of Victor Herbert's 1903 operetta, ''Babes in Toyland.'' The Brechtian-sounding ''recession spectacular,'' as it's billed, was adapted and directed by Michael Levinton, who is said to have spent seven seasons in a Baltimore community theater production of ''Babes.''
The show, at the Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is ''not recommended for actual children,'' warns the Little Lord theater company's Web site.
''A Molly Jolly Christmas'' is the first Christmas show starring Molly Dykeman (the alter ego of Andrea Alton), a self-described ''barely lucid poet/security guard'' who riffs on current events while in a pill-induced haze. Each performance will feature appearances by a rotating roster of guests, including the Village Voice gossip columnist Michael Musto, the burlesque artist Vicky Sin and the performance artist Shelly Mars.
Several gender-flexible fixtures on the performance circuit are returning to New York this year with topical shows.
The religiously anti-holiday performer Jackie Beat mounts a new show, ''The Nutcracker,'' which includes an original holiday number called ''It's Beginning to Look a Lot Like Syphilis.'' The downtown darling Justin Vivian Bond returns to the Abrons Arts Center with ''Mx. Bond's Austerity Measures: A Snow Job for the Masses,'' a politically minded, androgyny-embracing musical take on holiday cheer for the anti-Wall Street set.
If Scrooge had a Jewish sister with a scowl and a habit of kvetching about what's happening to the world, she might look like Jackie Hoffman in ''A Chanukah Charol.'' In her new solo show, inspired by Patrick Stewart's ''Christmas Carol,'' Ms. Hoffman meets the ghosts of Hanukkah Past, Present and Future, and gets a visit from the beloved Yiddish comedic actress Molly Picon.
FUTURE
THIS season brings several progressive-minded interpretations of ''A Christmas Carol.'' Scrooge meets steampunk in Pipe Dream Theater's dark musical ''3 Ghosts.'' In ''Reid Farrington's A Christmas Carol,'' Mr. Farrington, a former video designer for the Wooster Group, incorporates images from 35 movie versions of Dickens's novel in an evening of film, performance and installation art. The Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance brings back its show ''Los Nutcrackers'' (the subtitle isn't publishable here), a blending of ''The Nutcracker'' and ''A Christmas Carol'' in which a bickering gay couple meet a thug-angel who takes them back to the night they met while dancing to Lisa Lisa & Cult Jam.
Two shows skew to the dark side. Company XIV returns with its annual Christmas-season adaptation of ''Snow White,'' choreographed and directed by Austin McCormick. This multimedia-rich show, which runs at the Bond Street Theater in Brooklyn, takes its inspiration from the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, mixing opera, circus, dance, projection and live performance. While not recommended for very young children, the piece will appeal to tweens and above.
Also back for another season is ''Nutcracker: Rated R,'' a sex-, drug- and secrets-filled show about a grown-up ballerina named Clara who is transported back to New York in the early 1980s. Bits of Tchaikovsky's original score mix with modern music in a performance that also blends contemporary ballet, break dancing and burlesque. This year the show moves to the intimate nightclub Le Poisson Rouge.
Twisted 'Nutcrackers,' Offbeat 'Christmas Carols' and Hanukkah Latkes

HEADLINE: In Tough Times, a Boom in Cremations as a Way to Save Money

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
As Toni Kelly battled lymphoma, first with a bone marrow transplant and then with brutal rounds of chemotherapy, she worried obsessively that her four-year struggle would destroy her family's finances.
Her husband, Doug, refused to consider her pleas to stop pursuing costly therapies. But she knew that after she died, which she did on Sept. 29, there was one way she could keep from adding to the $200,000 in medical debt she would leave behind. Like a growing proportion of Americans, she said she wanted her body to be cremated.
''We did everything we could to cut down other costs, and one of the things Toni said was, 'Let's find out how much it costs to be cremated,' '' Mr. Kelly said. ''If there was a way we could save even $500 or $1,000, it didn't make a difference. Her major thing was not ruining the family.''
All but taboo in the United States 50 years ago, cremation is now chosen over burial in 41 percent of American deaths, up from 15 percent in 1985, according to the Cremation Association of North America. Economics is clearly one of the factors driving that change. 
The percentage of bodies that are cremated has risen steadily for years, for reasons ranging from spiritual to environmental. But a recent study shows that the increase has accelerated during the downturn, and many funeral home directors say they believe the economy is leading people to look for less expensive options.
The disposition of Ms. Kelly's remains cost about $1,600, and that total included a death notice, a death certificate and an urn bought online. It was a fraction of the $10,000 to $16,000 that is typically spent on a traditional funeral and burial.
Family and friends remembered Ms. Kelly, a 54-year-old artist, at a simple memorial service at the golf course in Virginia Beach where Mr. Kelly works as an assistant pro and where she liked to walk their dogs. It was the first cremation on her side of the family, Mr. Kelly said.
''Neither one of us felt that the body itself was really all that important,'' said Mr. Kelly, who raised two sons with his wife during their 28-year marriage. ''We had no interest in being put in the ground, no need for a memorial for the whole world to see. Her concern was the financial devastation she was bringing to the family.''
Many others share that concern, according to a national telephone survey of 858 adults conducted last year by the Funeral and Memorial Information Council. It found that one-third of those who chose cremation in 2010 said cost was a primary factor, up from 19 percent in 1990.
With the cremation rate rising one-third faster than at the middle of the last decade, the cremation association projects it will pass 50 percent by 2017 (still lagging behind Canada and much of Europe and Asia). Although state cremation rates vary widely, from 13 percent in Mississippi to 73 percent in Nevada, every state has experienced an increase since 2005.
Until recently, said Michael W. Nicodemus, president of the cremation association, concerns about cost rarely entered into his discussions about cremation with families at the Hollomon-Brown funeral homes in Virginia's Tidewater region, where he is a vice president. The rationale for cremation in the past was more typically that the family plot had become anachronistic in today's transient society and that cremation afforded relatives and friends more time to gather from afar for a memorial service.
Today, he said, nearly half of his consultations eventually turn to worries about money, and the cremation rate at the company's nine funeral homes has risen to 55 percent, up from 35 percent six years ago.
''People have lost money in the markets,'' Mr. Nicodemus said. ''Their retirements aren't what they used to be. A lot are living off Social Security.'' Some families, he said, have reversed burial plans because life insurance has lapsed or savings have been drained by uninsured medical expenses.
''We had six families to see yesterday, and all six were cremations,'' Mr. Nicodemus said. ''That tells me something.''
African-Americans, steeped in the traditions of open-casket funerals and rousing eulogies, remain the most resistant to cremation, according to surveys. But in the Virginia Tidewater, as elsewhere, even that cultural wall is crumbling.
Kenny Alexander, owner of Metropolitan Funeral Service in Norfolk, Va., said there was enough demand in the area's black community to make him consider buying a crematory, a $125,000 investment. He said 2 or 3 of every 10 families that come to him now asked for cremations. A decade ago, Mr. Alexander said, he did not even know how to price one.
''Unemployment, coupled with the downturn in the economy, the realities of people losing their savings and not being insured, has certainly caused African-American families to look at cremation in a different light,'' Mr. Alexander said.
In some instances, he added, families do not want friends to know because it may carry the stigma of financial hardship. ''We just say the burial is going to be private,'' he said.
Most mainstream religions have relaxed objections to cremation, which were tied to biblically based views of the body as a vessel for the soul and of a heaven populated by human forms.
''America is becoming Hinduized in this way,'' said Stephen Prothero, a professor of religion at Boston University and the author of ''Purified by Fire: A History of Cremation in America.'' ''We're increasingly seeing the human as essentially spiritual and gradually giving up on the Judeo-Christian idea of the person in the afterlife.''
Still, Lorice L. Ottenbacher of Virginia Beach explained that her husband's choice to be cremated, while largely motivated by his beliefs, also had an economic component.
''We talked about how expensive funerals were,'' said Ms. Ottenbacher, whose husband, Charles, died on Oct. 29 after a six-year struggle with Alzheimer's disease. ''He said, 'Well, just take me out to sea and let me swim with the dolphins and I'll be happy.' So that's what he's going to get.''
Whatever the precise cause for the shift, the funeral industry is having to adapt, making up for lost revenue with higher volume and more services, like catered receptions and ash pendants.
Sales of crematories -- there are about 2,200 across the nation, according to the cremation association -- are growing steadily as funeral home directors decide to perform cremations themselves rather than paying others to do so, said Paul F. Rahill, president of the cremation division at Matthews International, a major manufacturer. The ovens burn at 1,800 degrees for 90 to 120 minutes, and a grinder crushes the remaining bone into powder.
To broaden cremation's appeal to the environmentally minded, and to comfort people fearful of fire, the company is marketing a new ''biocremation'' process that dissolves the body with chemicals.
Families seem intrigued. ''In their minds,'' Mr. Rahill said, ''it's a gentler process.''

HEADLINE: The Listings

 BODY:
Pop
Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.
Beady Eye (Friday) After the contentious breakup of Oasis, the singer Liam Gallagher retained custody of his bandmates (save his brother Noel, the chief songwriter-guitarist) to form this new rock ensemble. Its debut, ''Different Gear, Still Speeding'' (Dangerbird), delivers the processed, raffish Brit-pop of Oasis with one floor-stomping exception: ''Bring the Light,'' an exhilarating retro-rock single with Jerry Lee Lewis-style piano. At 8 p.m., Terminal 5, 610 West 56th Street, Clinton, (800) 745-3000, terminal5nyc.com; $43 advance, or $48 at the door. (Stacey Anderson)
Jane Birkin (Sunday) The Serge Gainsbourg muse and increasingly politicized singer completes the American leg of her international tour, which honors the 20th anniversary of Gainsbourg's death. Her delicate French pop is delivered in unpredictable shifts between husky ardor and finely spun warble -- a sensual soundtrack that has inspired singers including Vanessa Paradis and Carla Bruni. With Joey Arias. At 7:30 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (800) 982-2787, the-townhall-nyc.org; $78.50 and $149. (Anderson) 
- Anna Calvi (Tuesday) Art-rock needed another quixotic blonde. Enter Ms. Calvi, a tenacious singer-songwriter from London whose Siouxie-worthy moans cap virtuosic strings and creaking, complex orchestrations. Her beguiling cover of Edith Piaf's ''Jezebel'' is a straight shot of gothic adrenaline. With Eleanor Friedberger. At 9 p.m., Music Hall of Williamsburg, 66 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn, (800) 745-3000, musichallofwilliamsburg.com; $8. (Anderson)
Celebration (Saturday) Their cabaret-laced psychedelia may veer toward the funereal, but this trio from Baltimore is wholly enjoyable live. The singer Katrina Ford is a guttural wailer in the vein of Merrill Garbus from Tune-Yards; the band's latest disc, ''Hello Paradise'' (Friends), added Eastern chromatics into the dark carousing. With Arboretum and Superhuman Happiness. At 9 p.m., Union Pool, 484 Union Avenue, at Meeker Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 609-0484, union-pool.com; $10. (Anderson)
- Gary Clark Jr. (Tuesday) This bluesy singer-guitarist may be vaunted as the next Hendrix nowadays, but he's also well suited to be the next Slowhand: at Alicia Keys's recent Keep a Child Alive charity gala, Mr. Clark decimated Eric Clapton's solo on the Beatles staple ''While My Guitar Gently Weeps,'' churning his distorted strings into a euphoric moment of psychedelia. His major-label debut is forthcoming. At 10:15 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (800) 745-3000, mercuryloungenyc.com; sold out. (Anderson)
The Devil Wears Prada (Tuesday) Despite the bewildering, self-imposed indignity of sharing their name with an Anne Hathaway rom-com, these screamo rockers from Ohio balance aggressively thrash guitars with blood-curdling histrionics. This slipshod Christian group may be the first religious rockers to take Bart Simpson's sage advice: ''All the best bands are affiliated with Satan.'' At 7 p.m., Best Buy Theater, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street, (800) 745-3000, bestbuytheater.com; $22. (Anderson)
Jose James (Thursday) The starry-eyed M.C. from Brooklyn has a grave edge to his gentle R&B cadences, which tugs his brassy hip-hop/jazz fusion back from the brink of schmaltz. The classy digressions of his recent breakthrough album, ''For All We Know'' (Verve), paint him as a burgeoning Gil Scott-Heron. At 7 p.m., Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org, museumtix.com; $12, or free for members. (Anderson)
Wyclef Jean (Sunday and Monday) His disc ''If I Were President: My Haitian Experience'' (Columbia) was viscerally felt yet fully theoretical; Mr. Jean did make a bid for the presidency of his native country, but it was rejected. Sadly, his reunion with the Fugees also seems like a flight of fancy by now. At 8 p.m., City Winery, 155 Varick Street, near Spring Street, South Village, (212) 608-0555, citywinery.com; $50. (Anderson)
- Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings (Tuesday and Wednesday) The finest soul-funk revivalists in town deliver a spectacle to rival James Brown on ''The T.A.M.I. Show'' each time they take the stage. It surely must be exhausting, being this marvelous, yet their new disc, ''Soul Time'' (Daptone), compiles outtakes and B-sides that show no dip in their exuberance. At 9 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (800) 745-3000, boweryballroom.com; sold out. (Anderson)
Spike Jones's 100th Birthday Celebration (Thursday) Parody pop's patron saint would surely have a few rude sound effects for today's political climate. As it is, this zany bandleader left behind a broad legacy to share with the next, irreverent generation; the raspberries punctuating the 1942 Hitler-baiting ode ''Der Fuehrer's Face'' are a master class of substantial absurdity. Expect the hosts Rob Schwimmer and Mark Stewart to be liberal with them. At 7 p.m. and 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $20. (Anderson)
John Lennon Tribute (Saturday) This celebration of the most radical Beatle is as renewable as his pacifist message; it has been held every year since the first anniversary of Mr. Lennon's untimely death. This 31st iteration includes a faithful revisiting of his first solo album, ''Plastic Ono Band'' (Apple), by the rock singer-guitarist Richard Barone, the gospel-soul dynamo Bettye LaVette and more. At 7 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com; $25 to $85. (Anderson)
- Darlene Love's Christmas Show (Sunday and Monday) Her lovelorn ''Christmas (Baby, Please Come Home)'' is a holiday rock show-stopper for the ages; her annual yuletide festivities at B. B. King's boite are a New York institution. Truly, this former protegee of Phil Spector has been an indelible voice in pop from the 1960s onward -- the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame certainly agreed when she was made one of the 2011 inductees. At 8 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $45 in advance, or $50 at the door. (Anderson)
The National (Monday to Thursday, through Dec. 17) The hyper-literate Brookynites continue to reap the windfall from ''High Violet'' (4AD), their nuanced chamber-rock effort from 2010, with this start of six consecutive nights at the Beacon. Fair enough; their baritone keening and propulsive drumming share a certain majesty with the space. At 8 p.m., Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (800) 745-3000, beacontheatrenyc.com; $39.50. (Anderson)
'A Not So Silent Night,' With Rufus and Martha Wainwright (Thursday) Almost every branch of the genetically blessed McGarrigle-Wainwright musical clan convenes under the Town Hall rafters: the patriarch (Loudon Wainwright III), his children (Rufus, Martha and Lucy) and their aunt and uncle (Anna McGarrigle and Sloan Wainwright). Sadly, the matriarch, the sublime folk artist Kate McGarrigle, passed away last year; she'll be honored by many friends, including Lou Reed and Laurie Anderson. At 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (800) 982-2787, the-townhall-nyc.org; $75. (Anderson)
Oh Land (Sunday) The Danish singer-songwriter Nanna Oland Fabricius employs her jazzy waver wisely: it makes even her harshest dismissals, like the wryly near-expletive ''Sun of a Gun,'' hitch with vulnerability. Her second electro-pop album, ''Oh Land'' (Epic), shares the smart club-ready charisma of Robyn and Lykke Li with added R&B flourishes. With Savoir Adore. At 8 p.m., Music Hall of Williamsburg, 66 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn, (800) 745-3000, musichallofwilliamsburg.com; $20. (Anderson)
Rocket From the Tombs (Monday) This band's roiling fury was too great to last -- in fact, these prog-rockers from Cleveland were together for just 12 terse months in 1974-75. Yet their scarcely tamped aggression -- in the singer Peter Laughner's garbled mutterings, in the serrated bursts from the guitarist Chris Cuda -- hinted at the punk explosion to follow shortly. Mr. Laughner died in 1977; the surviving members' reunion show is a long-awaited triumph for proto-punks the world over. At 9 p.m., Bell House, 149 Seventh Street, Gowanus, Brooklyn, (718) 643-6510, thebellhouseny.com; $15. (Anderson)
- Suuns (Saturday) The prog-rockers from Montreal take Hemingway-esque economy with their tunes, stacking small fragments of dissonant melody into dense, enormous waves. Their debut album, ''Zeroes QC'' (Secretly Canadian), merely suggests the sensational power of their live jams. With the Antlers. At 7 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (800) 745-3000, websterhall.com/events; $20. (Anderson)
The Weakerthans (Friday and Saturday) The tail end of these reflective Canadian rockers' Bowery residency promises king-sized nostalgia. Friday offers a full revisit of their languidly poppish ''Reconstruction Site,'' and Saturday tackles their atmospheric ''Reunion Tour'' (both Epitaph). At 9 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (800) 745-3000, boweryballroom.com; sold out. (Anderson)
- Why? (Thursday) A cabal of oft-prickly indie rockers, Why? displays subtly ingrained hip-hop undertones, as befits a band entrenched in the Anticon label collective of Oakland, Calif. This preview of their forthcoming album should yield major fireworks. At 7 p.m. and 10 p.m., Gould Hall, French Institute Alliance Francaise, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (800) 982-2787, ticketmaster.com; $20. (Anderson)
Yelle (Friday) This dance-pop sprite from St. Brieuc, France, performs alone and also lends her name to a delightful trio, whose ''Safari Disco Club'' (V2) is this year's brightest combustion of New Wave nostalgia and Europop bounce. Francophiles may recognize her cover of the 1980s French hit ''A Cause des Garcons'' from Emma Stone's recent, zany ''Saturday Night Live'' dance skit. With Housse de Racket. At 9 p.m., Music Hall of Williamsburg, 66 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn, (800) 745-3000, musichallofwilliamsburg.com; sold out. (Anderson)
Yuna (Sunday) Nirvana's ''Come as You Are'' is in good hands with this jazzy pop chanteuse from Malaysia; her cover of the grunge hit writhes with tempestuous keys and her gorgeous falsetto lilt, one reminiscent of Bjork for its fragile resolution. Yuma's debut, ''Decorate'' (Fader), of 2010, adds sing-song, Ronettes retroism to her folksy harmonies. With Emily Greene. At 8 p.m., S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940, sobs.com; $10. (Anderson)
Z100 Jingle Ball, With Lady Gaga and David Guetta (Friday) All the popular kids from the Pop Class of 2011 storm the Garden stage for truncated spectacles. Expect only four costume changes from Lady Gaga, as well as appearances by the French house artist David Guetta, the hipster dance spastics LMFAO, the deceptively bouncy rockers Foster the People, the powerhouse pop star Kelly Clarkson and more. At 7:30 p.m., Madison Square Garden, (866) 858-0008, thegarden.com; $51 to $451. (Anderson)

HEADLINE: Long Island Gets Big Grant In Cuomo's Competition

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
Long Island and three struggling upstate regions were the big winners Thursday in a competition for $785 million in one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's signature development initiatives.
In a session that resembled a pep rally, the state awarded more than $100 million each to four regions: Long Island; central New York, with its hub in Syracuse; western New York, oriented around Buffalo; and the sprawling North Country, which includes the Adirondacks. The state's six other regions each received $49 million to $69 million, including New York City, which received $66 million for 50 projects, many of them focused on lower-income parts of the city.
The largest New York City award was $29.5 million for modernizing the Hunts Point Produce Market in the South Bronx. But in an award that raised some eyebrows, the Ridgewood Bushwick Senior Citizens Council, founded by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez of Brooklyn, was awarded $845,806 for three projects despite allegations of financial improprieties against the council. 
The awards announcement, hosted by Maria Bartiromo of CNBC and full of upbeat pronouncements about the state's economic prospects, was a far cry from the usual gray press releases common for economic grants. The 10 regions had been asked to submit plans for growth, injecting competition into a process that had long been dominated by political calculations and cookie-cutter strategies.
Mr. Cuomo contrasted the competition with what he characterized as a lackadaisical attitude toward job creation in the past. He said that legislators had already agreed to provide money for a second round of awards next year.
''New York didn't get it; we just didn't get it,'' he said during the presentation in Albany. He compared the attitude of New York to what he saw around the country as housing secretary during the Clinton administration. ''There was almost an old hangover New York arrogance. We just assumed business was going to come here.''
He added, ''We learned the hard way that businesses are not cemented into the foundation.''
The 10 regions in the competition each had councils that put together economic plans and proposed investments based on their strengths in business, location and natural resources.
A five-person panel selected by Mr. Cuomo evaluated the plans developed by the regional councils and picked four winners. Each received $40 million in addition to individual grants that were evaluated by the regional councils and nine state agencies.
Central New York was awarded the largest combination of grants and tax credits, $103.7 million, for projects with focuses including clean energy, agribusiness and biotechnology. One such project, to complete the Central New York Biotechnology Research Center in Syracuse, will receive $2 million.
The North Country won $103.2 million, to be spent on high-tech and traditional manufacturing and the revival of small towns. The largest piece, $9.9 million, is to be spent on rehabilitating a 46-mile rail freight line.
Long Island, which was awarded $101.6 million, focused its proposal on reviving manufacturing and suburban smart growth. Projects include housing and transportation programs in economically troubled communities like Wyandanch, Brentwood and Hempstead; an electric grid project between Stony Brook University and Brookhaven National Laboratory; and a new cancer drug testing facility at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.
Western New York, awarded $100.3 million, focused on eight industry areas, including health and life sciences, advanced manufacturing and energy, with $5.1 million going to support the Roswell Park Cancer Institute's research into the medical uses of genetic sequencing.
A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, Josh Vlasto, did not respond directly to issues that have been raised about the Ridgewood Bushwick Senior Citizens Council in Brooklyn, which has been under federal investigation in the past for its financial practices. No charges have ever been filed.
But Mr. Vlasto did say in an e-mail, ''The individual projects won approval on the merits after a review by an independent group of businesses, community and labor leaders from all five boroughs.'' He added that the state's Department of Housing and Community Renewal would stay in contact with New York City's Department of Investigation ''about the status of any ongoing investigations.''
No one from the organization was available for comment.
A city investigation into the organization, completed in November, found a number of irregularities, including $218,659 in bonus and back pay in 2008 for its executive director, Christiana Fisher, that board members did not recall authorizing. That amount pushed the total pay for Ms. Fisher, who is also Assemblyman Lopez's campaign treasurer, in that fiscal year to $782,000.
Representatives of Long Island's council said they were pleased, both for bringing together often fractious suburban communities and for the inclusion of transit and revitalization projects for low-income communities.
''It makes all the difference in the world,'' said Stuart Rabinowitz, president of Hofstra University and co-chairman of Long Island's council.
''Long Island has so many different overlapping governments and so many self-appointed civic organizations, it's hard to find one nonpartisan or bipartisan group that speaks for the economic welfare of the entire region,'' he said. ''And this council tried to do that.''
